user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_irq_get_controller:
```c
static struct metal_irq_controller *metal_irq_get_controller(int irq)
{
	struct metal_list *node;
	struct metal_irq_controller *cntr;

	metal_list_for_each(&irq_cntrs, node) {
		int irq_base, irq_end;

		cntr = (struct metal_irq_controller *)
		       metal_container_of(node, struct metal_irq_controller,
					  node);
		irq_base = cntr->irq_base;
		irq_end = irq_base + cntr->irq_num;
		if (irq >= irq_base && irq < irq_end) {
			return cntr;
		}
	}
	return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions are present in the provided function. The code uses only standard C constructs: static function, struct pointers, local variable declarations, a for-style iteration via the macro metal_list_for_each, standard C cast, integer arithmetic and comparisons, and return NULL. There are no uses of known compiler extensions such as __attribute__, __asm, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), labels-as-values, unnamed/anonymous structs/unions (not shown), or other vendor-specific keywords (e.g. __builtin_*, __declspec). The only macros referenced (metal_list_for_each, metal_container_of) could potentially expand to extension-containing code, but their expansions are not present in this snippet; per the rule you requested, only explicit uses of language extensions visible in the given code are reported. Therefore there are no fragments here that explicitly use language extensions and no further investigation of fragments inside this snippet is required.
